instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.BKLT_PWM: What is BKLT_PWM? BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKLT_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Weird backlight issue
threads.message:
This one came in with severe water damage. After ultrasonic cleaning and fixing CPU VCORE power issue it started up with no backlight. I knew it would because it had a lot of corrosion around backlight circuitry. I changed all corroded resistors and caps around <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and also the <CHIP>LP8850</CHIP> itself. Some traces needed wire. Also the pulldown resistor on <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> was corroded so I have changed it and put a wire on the broken trace.

Now the backlight is working partially. When I start the computer backlight turns on. The brightness is 100% even if I turn it down. <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> is pulsing - long pulses on high brightness and short pulses on low brightness - but still full brightness around 40V on LCD connector. But when computer goes to sleep backlight does not come back on every time. Sometimes it comes right away - sometimes after 30 seconds - and sometimes not at all before I shut down and turn the machine back on. When backlight is not working after sleep then I get 19-20V on LCD connector.

I tried giving <SIGNAL>BKLT_PVM</SIGNAL> 3V from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> but still only 19V on backlight after sleep.

What am I missing ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Weird backlight issue
threads.message:
Seems like an issue on PWM pin. Remove <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and measure on diode mode on <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>. Could also be a bad <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>. Also measure diode mode on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R9714</RESISTOR>/16 and pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R9741</RESISTOR>. Also check value of these resistors.
Oh and the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> you used, have you used these of the same batch before? They do have an EEPROM with settings in them...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Weird backlight issue
threads.message:
Thanks Duke for pointing me in the direction of measuring diode mode on <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> with <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> removed. It showed up that I had a microscopic OL around the probe point for <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>. I couldn't even see it in the microscope on highest zoom setting. But the multimeter saw it :) Made a trace and brightness now is adjustable and backlight wakes from sleep.

Thanks again you can mark this one solved. Thumbs up!
